security_audit.summary: This is a markdown-only documentation skill containing informational guidance about Go testing patterns. No executable code, scripts, or file system operations exist. All 55 static findings are false positives caused by the static analyzer misidentifying markdown documentation and Go code examples as executable security threats.

content.value_statement: Writing tests in Go can be challenging without guidance on patterns and best practices. This skill provides comprehensive examples for table-driven tests, mocking, integration testing with containers, and performance benchmarks.
actual_capabilities: Create table-driven tests with test cases and error scenarios
Implement interface-based mocking for dependency isolation
Write integration tests using test containers
Set up test fixtures with setup and teardown patterns
Test HTTP handlers with httptest recorder
limitations: Does not execute actual Go tests or compile code
Does not generate test files in your project
Does not run tests or collect coverage reports
Does not integrate with CI/CD pipelines

output_examples.input: How do I write tests for a function that adds two numbers?
output: Use table-driven tests with t.Run for each case
Test positive numbers, negative numbers, mixed signs, and zeros
Use t.Errorf to report failures with expected vs actual values
Group related tests in a slice of test cases for maintainability

output_examples.input: How can I test my HTTP handler without starting a real server?
output: Use httptest.NewRequest to create mock HTTP requests
Use httptest.NewRecorder to capture handler responses
Assert on response status code and body content
Test both success and error scenarios

best_practices: Test behavior, not implementation. Focus on inputs and outputs rather than internal details.
Use t.Helper() to mark helper functions for clearer error reporting in test output.
Run independent tests in parallel with t.Parallel() to speed up test suite execution.
anti_patterns: Avoid one test with many assertions. Split into focused test cases for better debugging.
Do not skip t.Cleanup() for resource management. Always defer cleanup in tests.
Avoid hardcoding test data. Use test fixtures or factories instead for maintainability.

faq.question: What Go versions are supported?
faq.answer: Works with Go 1.14 and later. Examples use standard library testing package.

faq.question: What is the maximum test complexity supported?
faq.answer: No limits. Patterns scale from simple unit tests to complex integration test suites.

faq.question: How do I integrate with existing test frameworks?
faq.answer: Compatible with testify, ginkgo, gocheck, and other testing libraries.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my project files?
faq.answer: No. This skill provides guidance and examples only. It does not read or write project files.

faq.question: Why are my tests failing?
faq.answer: Check that your test file ends with _test.go and is in the same package as your code.

faq.question: How is this different from Go built-in testing?
faq.answer: This skill enhances Go built-in testing with patterns and best practices.
